story:
Our Story

Rubber Soul Yoga Revolution opened in 2006 in Athens, GA.  We have successfully offered yoga to the community on a donation basis.  Donation yoga allows people of all income levels and all job types to give yoga a try and--hopefully--stick with it.  In 2009 we began offering a yoga teacher training, also at a highly affordable price.  The teacher training brings students of yoga to a deeper level of understanding, where issues of global poverty, deforestation, climate change, industrial agriculture, and health epidemics are encountered.  While yoga is initially a personal health initiative, it eventually becomes a universal health opportunity.  Rubber Soul encourages all practitioners to become activists.


Now we would like to bring Rubber Soul to New York City. 


The Impact

Students are constantly thanking me for setting up a yoga studio on a donation basis.  When people are out of funds, as many are these days, they are often also in crisis.  Rubber Soul accepts everyone, gives people a safe place, and nourishes the spirit.  I received this note last month:  "Dear Rubber Soul, I started learning yoga here right after I hit my lowest-low.  I have since taken my life back and pulled myself up by my bootstraps.  It wouldn't have been possible without this studio and each and every beautiful, wonderful instructor.  I love life.  Thank you for reminding me."  These are hard times.  Yoga helps.


New York is a city of extremes.  While many can afford special care, others cannot.  Rubber Soul sees yoga as the first step toward not only helping others but showing others how they themselves can help others.  In this way, we can seed the revolution that very much needs to happen.  Humanity faces so many challenges in this upcoming century.  In order to succeed, we must learn to give to others.  As a country, the United States must shift from the world's top energy user to a nation that participates in a global downsizing, so that all of humanity may occupy our small planet.  This is the sort of thing that we teach alongside yoga.  What better place to do it than in New York City itself?

What We Need & What You Get

In this campaign, we are asking for a very specific amount for a very specific purpose.  $3800 is one month's rent for a 1200 sq. ft. commercial loft space in Manhattan.  This month will allow us to get the word out.  It will give us an extra 31 days to get the ball rolling.  If the campaign goes over $3800, that will give us even more time.  Wonderful!  


When we began Rubber Soul in Athens, our website had 894 hits.  A month later, it had 1424 hits--almost twice as many.  Now, six years later, it gets 5653 hits per month.  This shows that businesses take time to build.  The early months can be expensive.  In Athens, where the rent is around $1200, this isn't much of a trouble.  In New York, it could be a grave difficulty.  Help us offset this growing period!


Funding for Rubber Soul comes entirely from the people who take yoga classes.  They donate per class.  This isn't a charitable donation for them, since they are receiving a service.  It is impossible to receive grants from larger agencies, since the population being served is undefined.  It is anyone who walks through the door.  


If you donate today, you can have perks.  For $10, you can have a free class at Rubber Soul, either in Athens or in New York City once we open in April.  For $25, you can come for a week as many times as you like.  For $50, you can come for two weeks.  For $100, you can come for a month.  For more than $100, you can decide how many times you'd like to come to classes as our guest.  It could be for months, years, or even decades.  Your generosity now is of extra value, because it comes at a pivotal time.  Become our angel and never pay for a yoga class again!


Other Ways You Can Help

Another way to help, whether you donate today or not, is by getting the word out.  Tell people via your social media of this campaign.  Also, let your friends in New York know of our opening.  April 2012, near Union Square.
story_txt:
Our Story
Rubber Soul Yoga Revolution opened in 2006 in Athens, GA.  We have successfully offered yoga to the community on a donation basis.  Donation yoga allows people of all income levels and all job types to give yoga a try and--hopefully--stick with it.  In 2009 we began offering a yoga teacher training, also at a highly affordable price.  The teacher training brings students of yoga to a deeper level of understanding, where issues of global poverty, deforestation, climate change, industrial agriculture, and health epidemics are encountered.  While yoga is initially a personal health initiative, it eventually becomes a universal health opportunity.  Rubber Soul encourages all practitioners to become activists.

Now we would like to bring Rubber Soul to New York City. 


The Impact
Students are constantly thanking me for setting up a yoga studio on a donation basis.  When people are out of funds, as many are these days, they are often also in crisis.  Rubber Soul accepts everyone, gives people a safe place, and nourishes the spirit.  I received this note last month:  "Dear Rubber Soul, I started learning yoga here right after I hit my lowest-low.  I have since taken my life back and pulled myself up by my bootstraps.  It wouldn't have been possible without this studio and each and every beautiful, wonderful instructor.  I love life.  Thank you for reminding me."  These are hard times.  Yoga helps.

New York is a city of extremes.  While many can afford special care, others cannot.  Rubber Soul sees yoga as the first step toward not only helping others but showing others how they themselves can help others.  In this way, we can seed the revolution that very much needs to happen.  Humanity faces so many challenges in this upcoming century.  In order to succeed, we must learn to give to others.  As a country, the United States must shift from the world's top energy user to a nation that participates in a global downsizing, so that all of humanity may occupy our small planet.  This is the sort of thing that we teach alongside yoga.  What better place to do it than in New York City itself?

What We Need & What You Get
In this campaign, we are asking for a very specific amount for a very specific purpose.  $3800 is one month's rent for a 1200 sq. ft. commercial loft space in Manhattan.  This month will allow us to get the word out.  It will give us an extra 31 days to get the ball rolling.  If the campaign goes over $3800, that will give us even more time.  Wonderful!  

When we began Rubber Soul in Athens, our website had 894 hits.  A month later, it had 1424 hits--almost twice as many.  Now, six years later, it gets 5653 hits per month.  This shows that businesses take time to build.  The early months can be expensive.  In Athens, where the rent is around $1200, this isn't much of a trouble.  In New York, it could be a grave difficulty.  Help us offset this growing period!

If you donate today, you can have perks.  For $10, you can have a free class at Rubber Soul, either in Athens or in New York City once we open in April.  For $25, you can come for a week as many times as you like.  For $50, you can come for two weeks.  For $100, you can come for a month.  For more than $100, you can decide how many times you'd like to come to classes as our guest.  It could be for months, years, or even decades.  Your generosity now is of extra value, because it comes at a pivotal time.  Become our angel and never pay for a yoga class again!


Other Ways You Can Help
Another way to help, whether you donate today or not, is by getting the word out.  Tell people via your social media of this campaign.  Also, let your friends in New York know of our opening.  April 2012, near Union Square.

story:
My Fathers's Cancer Golf Drive

My Father (Robert Kimpinski) has been recently diagnosed with late stage 4 prostate cancer. With this grim news I wanted to do something special for him to show my appreciation.

 The reason for this campaign is really two folds. First part being mainly my father and his prostate cancer and the second is our local community owned golf course which my father has helped build.

Dad was born and raised in Shoal Lake and has remained in this community his entire life. This local community owned 9 hole golf course has recently fallen on financial hardship. The course is over 50 years old and alot of hard work has been put into it so we would like to see it remain in our community forever.

 http://www.shoallake.ca/whattodo.htm

I am trying to raise enough money in honor of my father to eliminate the debt that has been acquired over the years due to maintenance and upkeep of this course. With a fresh start I believe this community owned treasure will remain in the community forever.

I am not sure how much time my father has left and I would like to do this donation in my fathers honor before he passes. 

 If the financial goal is reached ($150,000) anything further will be donated to the http://ca.movember.com in his name.

Donation Levels of Recognition

Silver – under $25 – Silent recognition

Bronze – Under $100 – Name listed on plaque in club house.

Gold – $100 and over - Name listed on monument on Hole #2 - A monument will be built in my Dad honor.

Hopefully you will see fit to donate to this cause to secure Lakeside Golf Courses future and to provide a legacy to which my father would be proud of. . .

If you would like to donate by other sources please send payment to:

Robert Kimpinski, Box 265, Shoal Lake, Manitoba, R0J1Z0

Make cheques or Money Orders payable to: Lakeside Golf Course

story:
Our Story

Currently there is no all inclusive birth center in Los Angeles AND there is a critical shortage of midwives of color. The Community Birth Center (TCBC) is born out of a need and a vision; and with your support- we will reach our goal.  We believe that financial circumstances should not exclude anyone from caring,   supportive, safe midwifery services- and therefore have created this birth center to serve our local community and all of those who believe in our mission and services.  Further, by creating this space- we will serve as a hub for all birth practitioners and a training ground for those interested in becoming an apprentice- or simply donating their time and effort to this grassroots movement.The Community Birth Center belongs to us all.


The Impact

DIsparities in the United States, continue to show that low income and minority families have the highest rates of maternal mortality, infant mortality, preterm birth, and very low birth weight babies.  According to the NPR, Minorities and low income women are about 60 percent more likely to deliver babies early, and black infants are about 230 percent more likely to die before their first birthdays.  This statistic is horrifying and the question is why?

Experts state that lower use of prenatal care, less adequate care, and high stress associated with lower socioeconomic status, contribute to women being three to four times more likely to die in pregnancy.  The Community Birth Center, aims to address this issue head on.  We will provide quality care, to all communities regardless of race or socioeconomic background.  We want to provide quality care to EVERY WOMEN!  We ARE our community and we ARE the ones we have been waiting for.


What We Need & What You Get

We need your support. By word of mouth, social networks (i.e. Facebook, Twitter, etc), we must get the word out.  Financially we will meet our goal, with the help of all who share in this dream.     Let's make this happen.  On May 5th our Indiegogo Campaign will conclude with The Grand Opening of The Community Birth Center.  May 5th is also The International Day of the Midwife!

Your contributions will go toward ensuring TCBC stays open and runs smoothly. We plan on taking full paying clients ($4,500 for homebirth or birth center, which includes standard prenatal bloodwork & 1 ultrasound) and at least 1 discounted family PER MONTH.  This means that with your help, we will be able to not only open this much needed birth center, but we can also offer services for FREE each month, to a family in financial need.  The money will also go to our website, rent, flooring, paint, birth tub installation, shower installation & our tankless water heater. (This is to ensure we never run out of hot water!!!)

We all have the right to make informed decisions and seek out the birth experience of our dreams-and with your support the Los Angeles area, will not only gain a much needed/wanted/dreamed of birth center- we can also offer families the opportunity that might not have it otherwise.


Other Ways You Can Help

Help us make this dream come true! We are a grassroots organization in the realest sense of the term. What we have accomplished so far is because of the sheer will, determination, and generosity of a very small group of people. Please share this link with others who can help us reach our goal.  Each dollar counts!!!

story:
Short Summary

Have Heart is a company started by Ed Edge, with the sole purpose of improving people's quality of life by improving their health. We also empower people by giving them the proper knowledge required for healthy lifestyles.

This campaign is solely to fund the 50 summer classes in the Richmond Public Housing Developments. All classes are 100% free for the residents and are held in the neighborhoods themselves.

Classes include: Zumba, Yoga, Pilates, Nutrition & Cooking, and Boot Camp


What Your funding Provides:

There are no administrative costs with Have Heart so all of the money goes towards hiring the best instructors and the equipment used. We also provide many of our clients with pedometers and water bottles to insure healthy lifestyles outside of the weekly classes.


The Impact!

Each of our classes happen on either once or twice a week in each neighborhood. classes range from 15-75, so with this campaign alone we are able to help over 1,000 Richmond residents get healthy, that would otherwise have no access to fitness instruction.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute today, that is totally fine, perhaps you know someone that can! Please get the word out about the profound impact and importance of this project. Ed Edge currently gives 80% of his income to this company but that still isn't enough to fund all of the classes. With your assistance, we can spread the love even farther

story:
PLEASE HELP US GO BEYOND 5,000! 

That was the default goal, and as we know they will both need more than that. Thank you so much.

Our Story

Brad Guerrero and Shaunna Heth were part of a shooting in their East Hollywood home. The shooter shot at 4 roommates, and burned the house down. Shaunna and Bradwere both shot multiple times and were taken to the hospital in critical condition. They are slowly recovering and will be undergoing multiple surgeries soon. Shaunna does not have medical insurance, and lost all of her belongings. They will both need donations to get them and their families through this tragedy.

Here is the L.A Times Link on the story:

http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-hollywood-fire-20120217,0,7259584.story 

What We Need

We can assure you that all of this money is going towards helping Brad and Shaunna. Instead of flowers or balloons, please donate to their fund.


If you have any questions, you can email us at bradshaunna@yahoo.com


Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word! Posting this link on your Facebook, Twitter or any blogging sites! Your support is very much appreciated!

story:
Our Story

John Foster has been a personal trainer for about 7 years.  At one point, he grew frustrated with the whole gym environment, the superficiality of it all.  He had always been really interested in philosophy and spirituality, and after finding some key ideas such as barefoot training and Integral Philosophy, he started to develop Life Warrior.  He began to combine barefoot training, body-weight training, yoga, mindfulness, Integral Philosophy and plant-based nutrition, and found that looking good and being healthy  could be much more than a superficial activity.  

Meanwhile, Amanda Russcol was teaching yoga, studying nutrition, opening vegan restaurants and going to school to be a life coach.  After returning from studying yoga in the Himalayas, she moved to Denver and began teaching yoga, mindfulness, meditation and plant-based nutrition.  She was working on building a similar program to John's at a retreat center on a small island in the Bahamas (which is an ongoing project).

John met Amanda as he was trying to get his holistic gym going.  They were amazed at how much they had in common, and decided to join forces to create a space where people could learn all they need to know to take control of their minds, bodies and spirits.  

The space is a studio in Littleton, Colorado, about 20 minutes south of Denver.  It is in an amazing healing center that includes massage therapy, chiropractic, acupuncture and organic spa treatments.   The Life Warrior space is equipped with a jungle gym, kettlebells, lots of fun body-weight training and boot camp equipment, yoga swings, mats, blocks and more.  What you won't find are typical gym machines - we want to teach people how to move so that they can bring their workouts with them wherever they go.  Life Warrior is getting ready to open, but still needs lots of assistance (that means MONEY - from you!) to buy the rest of the equipment, pay teachers, market our services and become the most fun, natural, progressive lifestyle space around!

We've been very lucky to gain the help of Janet, who lost over 100 pounds with John, as our bookkeeper and general over-seer.  She's amazing with numbers and, as she won't be part of the day-to-day operations, she will be in a great place to look at the big picture and keep us focused on it!  We're also so glad to have Carly, a yoga instructor and marketing whiz, who already has our grassroots campaign up and running.  


Our vision is to open Life Warrior training centers all over the United States and eventually the world. We want to create true life warriors who will transform themselves, their communities, and their environment. This project is exactly what health, training, and community will begin to look like in the year of 2012 and beyond. 

The Impact 

Our impact on others is our whole point!  We want to change the way the world views health and experiences fitness.  We want to give back in big ways, and have already helped to sponsor fundraising events for local non-profits.  We want people to learn how to control their stress levels through mindfulness, make conscious and smart decisions when they eat and build strength and stamina in a very functional manner.  

Specifically, we will offer a wide range of fitness, philosophy, nutrition and meditation classes, including boot camp, yoga, flying yoga, group weight-loss challenges, cooking and mindfulness classes.  We will create a strong community, making our clients more excited to come and be among friends and creating an atmosphere of group momentum.  We want to get the community involved in all kinds of projects to better the Denver area and the world, from benefit dinners for local charities to group runs to tree-planting to all kinds of education, and everything in between.  Volunteering is a big part of our mission!


What We Need & What You Get


We need $13,000.  Here's what it will buy:
$6000 for training equipment
$2000 for yoga swings and yoga equipment
$1500 for selective and grassroots marketing for the first year
$500 for books and equipment to sell
$1500 to help with the rent and start-up costs
$2000 for paying our teachers for the first two to three months, when we will be giving huge discounts to get to know the community and let them get to know us.

We are exploring other options for funding, such as loans from clients who love us!  Whatever we don't get from you, we will beg and borrow from someone else, but the time it takes to find the money elsewhere will take our time away from our goal of helping our clients, one by one.  So please, if you believe in our mission, if you want a place like ours in your neighborhood someday, please vote with your dollars, give what you can!  We will be so grateful!  Each person involved in this project is passionate about what we are doing, and in it to make a real and sustainable change in our world, and every dollar you give will go towards that goal, too!  Be sure to check out our perks, and check back in on our progress!


Other Ways You Can Help

Help us in person or through your online presence!  If you can't give money, or patronage, let other people know about us!  Maybe they live near us and want to come check us out, or maybe they want to throw a few bucks our way!  "Like" us on Facebook, post links to this site on your blog, tell your friends, neighbors and rich uncles!  You can also help us by living your best life, being healthy, eating more vegetables and being kind to everyone around you.  If you want ideas on how to do those things, visit our website - www.LifeWarriorCoaching.com.  We want to help you, even if you don't help us!  :)

story:
Short Summary

Our mission is to work with the people of Sierra Leone to achieve a higher level of development by providing access to clean water.  In practical terms, this means building improved water sources in areas where none exist and repairing water sources that are in disrepair.  We depend on donations – large and small – to accomplish our work.  And we are grateful for all of the gracious help that pours in from people across the globe.

Founded on the idea that our personal connection to Sierra Leone is our fundamental strength, we understand that commitment is a long-term proposition.  So far, small steps have marked our beginning as we rely on generous donations and the dedication of local craftsmen to fix broken water pumps and restroom facilities in rural villages.  We appreciate your support and welcome your involvement.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $3,000 to build water wells in January 2013.

Organized in August 2012, we’re a new non-profit that’s off to a strong start. We’ve repaired two broken pumps in Sierra Leone’s Pujehun District, one in Blama Massaquoi, and one in Funiko.  

Whenever possible, we document our projects with photos and video footage.   In cases where this is not possible, we collect testimonials from community members.  Please check our blog for more details!

The Impact

We approach each project with our intimate knowledge of Sierra Leone, which allows us to build strong partnerships in the communities where we work.  We partner with communities that want and need help but that are also interested in helping themselves.  We hire local labor to build water sources in our partner communities.  Our goal is for the people of Sierra Leone to have reliable potable water sources.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, please help in other critical ways:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about what we do.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.
story_txt:
Short SummaryOur mission is to work with the people of Sierra Leone to achieve a higher level of development by providing access to clean water.  In practical terms, this means building improved water sources in areas where none exist and repairing water sources that are in disrepair.  We depend on donations – large and small – to accomplish our work.  And we are grateful for all of the gracious help that pours in from people across the globe.Founded on the idea that our personal connection to Sierra Leone is our fundamental strength, we understand that commitment is a long-term proposition.  So far, small steps have marked our beginning as we rely on generous donations and the dedication of local craftsmen to fix broken water pumps and restroom facilities in rural villages.  We appreciate your support and welcome your involvement.What We Need & What You GetWe need $3,000 to build water wells in January 2013.Organized in August 2012, we’re a new non-profit that’s off to a strong start. We’ve repaired two broken pumps in Sierra Leone’s Pujehun District, one in Blama Massaquoi, and one in Funiko.  Whenever possible, we document our projects with photos and video footage.   In cases where this is not possible, we collect testimonials from community members.  Please check our blog for more details!The ImpactWe approach each project with our intimate knowledge of Sierra Leone, which allows us to build strong partnerships in the communities where we work.  We partner with communities that want and need help but that are also interested in helping themselves.  We hire local labor to build water sources in our partner communities.  Our goal is for the people of Sierra Leone to have reliable potable water sources.Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can't donate, please help in other critical ways:
Get the word out and make some noise about what we do.
Use the Indiegogo share tools!
And that’s all there is to it.

story:
My name is Ilya Brown, I have been visiting India for over 10 years now and really felt like I should get involved with what is happening in this country.
I am already involved in an organisation for the disabled in Switzerland and was hoping to expand this to India where I wanted to start a fundraiser for it.
With the money you will donate, I will personally help the organisation and hope to bring enough money to provide better class and therapy materials.
I can think of no better way to start the year than with a wave of people standing up together to say they want to be part of the movement to end extreme poverty.

Please take a moment to share this campaign with friends and family and help provide a better lifestyle for both disabled children and adults.

story:
"Paladin" -  Family Advocacy for Alzheimer's Disease

What I can't do, WE CAN DO! 

How can I care for my loved one? What resources are available? How can I find what I need to help me care for my loved one? What next? 

When individuals are faced with the diagnosis that a family member has any form of dementia they are overwhelmed with questions.

With Alzheimer's disease cases mushrooming in numbers, we felt an advocacy packet to distribute upon diagnosis is long overdue. Resources are available, however, not always readily accessible. Our goal is to help make  resources more readily accessible to family members of all ages.

Our objective is to provide an information packet to help families cope with the challenges of Alzheimer's Disease and to help the diagnosed individual. This packet does both, helps the families and their loved one; the family members will get much needed support which will help them become better care-givers. The knowledge and insight shared in this packet helps by providing more skills to deal with the problems that arise and more understanding of how this illness impacts their loved one. These skills  and understanding will go a long way toward easing the devastation of the journey for everyone involved.

As a group of authors we have each been impacted by the devastation of Alzheimer's Disease. We have come together with our respective books and unique experiences to offer support and resources that we could not find when we first started on our respective journeys. Our own experience has been there is a gap between books that are too clinical and sometimes depressing or written for medical professionals compared to hands-on, experiential, positive books that can connect lay people with professionals. It is our mission to fill that gap.

We are working together to provide information about organizations and resources to families coping with the challenges of a loved one's Alzheimer's Disease. One of our goals is to make this package available nationwide. Our "Paladin" packet will include our respective books, a list of resources in our booklet, " Dementia Resource List for Paladin -  A Family Advocacy Packet"  including information to access state specific Living Wills and or Advance Directive information  to aid people when they are initially overwhelmed with this devastating diagnosis as well as support them on their journey through this disease. We will create a website which will be linked to our websites making available an electronic version of "Paladin" and links to other books and websites we believe are excellent resources. We will also have contact information available to get hard copy packages available for those who do not use the internet.

People suffering from Alzheimer's Disease are often helped by focusing on a comfortable life experience such as coloring, painting, creating, singing, and listening to music.Our packet will include an activity type book, such as a coloring book for people of all ages, as we have found pleasant distractions are necessary for family members of all ages. 
It’s been our experience there are not enough resources for children over the age of 6 or for adult family members and caregivers. Our mission is to fill this gap as a package resource for families as well as a resource for memory care advocates to provide interactive tools for their clients and patient families.


Our "tag line" is a quote from a disabled Veteran who through the support of other Veterans learned, "What I can't do, WE can do"! 


Budget: $29,000.00 Goal includes expenses as approximated. Non-profit status will be applied for upon successful fundraising campaign.

Approximate Expenses:  Initial packet materials for number of packets (purchased from respective authors and participants at wholesale rates) to be determined by funds raised @ $50.00 per packet with the initial goal of 200 packets = $10,000.00; Design website: $5,000.00; Web Maintenance 2 Years - $4,000.00; Outreach/Marketing: Approximately 80 hours at $150.00 = $5,000.00; Miscellaneous Expenses, mailing materials, stationary supplies, communications, mileage, etc. - $5,000.00

Immediate/Short Term Goals: We hope to create as many packets as possible and get them in the hands of the families dealing with Alzheimer's Disease as soon as possible.

Long Range Goals: We have several long range goals including, but not limited to, continued fundraising which will allow us to provide our packet to families and individuals/caregivers at little or no expense long term. We will strive to continually update the packet as new research is done and new resources become available. And it is our intent to continue this project until a cure for Alzheimer's Disease is found.

Inspiration
Our collective inspiration has been how Alzheimer's disease and dementia has engulfed our lives and the lives of our extended families. Each of our experiences were unique but the one thing we all had in common was seeing a need to help all families be better informed, prepared and enlightened when this affliction enters the door. Alexandra's mom's entire family; siblings and father, were/are impacted by dementia so this is an issue that hits right in her home. But the inspiration to write her book, "Green Kitty" came one day when she was working in assisted living. 

There was this wonderful feisty little lady who loved to tell about the time that she kissed Elvis Presley. She always ended the story by saying that he would still be alive if he had married her! But one day her 10 year old granddaughter came to visit and she was having a bad memory day. The poor old woman repeated herself several times and asked the same question more than once to her granddaughter. The young girl then rudely and loudly said "Grandma- you've already said that three times." The sweet grandmother's face just fell. Alexandra could see from across the room the woman's feelings had been hurt and remembers thinking to herself, "Someone ought to have told that young girl what was going on with her grandmother, what to expect and how to react to it." 

That’s what made her decide to use her collection of amusing animal stories to write a book that would help children ages 8-12 have a better understanding of dementia.

His Name Was Merle - Our Journey Through Alzheimer's Disease

"His Name Was Merle-" Our Journey through Alzheimer's Disease" by Lynda Jane Olander Converse. While everyone's journey is unique, there are common threads we experience and as we share our experiences and solutions we will be helpful to one another until there is a cure for this dread disease.

This book is a loving tribute to our family and especially, my dad. It is also a resource as I hope you gain from our experiences and find the hope, courage and comfort in these pages to help you in some small way as you travel this path minute by minute, hour by hour and day by day. 

How does it help people live well:
Alzheimer’s disease hits many families, leaving them clinging to memories and unsure of the future. "In His Name Was Merle - Our Journey through Alzheimer’s disease", I present, through our story, information you may be wondering about or have not considered. This includes:

• Care questions you will face early on: Can your loved one be cared for at home? How do you know when it is time to consider moving your loved one to a specialized facility?

• Issues faced by the primary caregiver.

• Emotional needs of the primary caregiver: What should your family consider when deciding on the best care options for your loved one?

• Emotions, including guilt or anxiety, over decisions related to the care and treatment of your loved one.

• Questions to consider when faced with tough end-of-life discussions.

• Coping methods and ideas.

Staying Alive In A Sea of Forgetfulness

"Staying Alive in a Sea of Forgetfulness"- An especially important part of this advocacy project is to connect family members and caregivers in a way that makes a better life for the person with dementia. Gary Joseph LeBlanc's book, "Staying Afloat in a Sea of Forgetfulness" is an especially valuable resource on this subject and is also included in this package. 
Gary Joseph LeBlanc , is the author of “Staying Afloat in a Sea of Forgetfulness,” and co- author of “While I Still Can.” He is also, a weekly columnist of “Common Sense Care-giving” published in the Tampa Tribune and Hernando Today and many other health publications. 

His writings and speaking events utilize his 3,000 plus days and nights of personal care-giving experience while taking care of his father to help other Alzheimer’s and dementia caregivers cope with the everyday challenges and emotional struggles of caring for the memory-impaired.

LeBlanc is founder of the Alzheimer’s/Dementia Hospital Wristband Project, currently being piloted at Brooksville Regional Hospital in Hernando County, Florida.  The goal is to have a special wristband placed on patients with dementia and symbol placed on the doorway when a hospital admission is required so that all healthcare providers are aware of the unique needs of these individuals.

Green Kitty

"Green Kitty" is going to be included in this advocacy packet in addition to "His Name Was Merle" and "Staying Afloat In A Sea of Forgetfulness" and other resources for people whose families who have been impacted by Alzheimer's disease. "Green Kitty" teaches compassion and inter-generational togetherness. It was written by Alexandra Faer Bryan, R.N., to help reduce the stress associated with this devastating illness and to show that people with this diagnosis still have value to their families. People in nursing homes and assisted living are often lonely and are not visited enough.  "Green Kitty" encourages more visits between families. The work prepares children for the changes that will occur in their grandparents or loved ones who have this diagnosis. It also promotes the need for charity and community service.The book is about a grandmother being visited by her grandchild and revolves around  entertaining stories as told by the grandmother. Helpful information and suggestions about dementia and Alzheimer's disease were woven into the story line in such a way as to not be overwhelming.

"Dementia Resource List for Paladin -  A Memory Advocacy Packet for Families": This resource list was created through research by all the "Paladin" project participants and developed by Alexandra Faer Bryan to be included in the packet. It provides book lists, links to other helpful websites and blogs and a brief overview of many concerns and potential complications that families might incur.

Dad's Eagle Tree  Original Photograph by LJC

Merle's Family

Dad's Eagle Tree - Original Oil Painting by LJC

story:
Summary

Hello! I am Dr. Igor Reizenson, DDS, dentist and inventor of the CLEARsmile device. My goal is to change the face of dental hygiene as we know it. 

The CLEARsmile project is seeking to raise funds to develop a device that will replace the traditional toothbrush, toothpaste, floss and mouth rinse. It will allow kids, elderly, and everyone in between to have a much easier time keeping their teeth and gums clean and healthy.

The CLEARsmile device is essentially a pressure wash for your teeth and gums that hits every angle, simultaneously. It blasts and dissolves bad dental bacteria easily from every nook and cranny. The purpose of this campaign is to raise the funds necessary to build a fully functioning CLEARsmile prototype. Getting to the prototype stage is huge hurdle that I need to overcome in order to put a CLEARsmile device in homes everywhere. 

What We Need & What You Get

I had a study done by Harvard Business graduates and determined that to get a working CLEARsmile prototype is going to cost about $750,000. And yes, I realize that is a seriously intimidating number! I've come up with some what I think are great incentives so I hope that you will seriously consider donating and becoming part of dental hygiene history.  

The Impact

I came up with the idea for CLEARSmile while working in the Veterans Hospital and doing my weekly rounds seeing elderly bed ridden patients not able to clean their teeth, and nurses not able to do it for them. This compromised their healing and increased their stay in the hospital.

I went from that residency to doing community dentistry on mobile buses for under privileged kids all across the state of Georgia. Providing dental care for these two populations revealed a great need for an oral hygiene device that would be quick, easy, predictable and effective.

I believe the CLEARsmile device can change the face of dental health by replacing traditional brushing and flossing methods for dental hygiene. 

Other Ways You Can Help

I realize that not everyone can make a donation to the CLEARsmile project and that's ok. There are other ways that you can help out. Fundraising thrives on getting the most number of people possibly to learn about a project. Even if you can't donate, please spread the word about CLEARsmile. Every little bit helps!

story:
Me and Wheelchair Racing

With your help, I am trying to raise a total of £5000 to get a racing wheelchair  so I can go back to racing training. I already have been granted £2500 towards it by a charity and now I'm looking for help raising the other £2500.

Through online donations I am hoping to reach a target of £500 in 60 days

The Wheelchair

Racing wheelchairs are custom built for every person as they have to become an extension of your body. For this reason they are very expensive and I have to go to London to be fitted for this. With your help I will be able to get back to racing before the end of the year.

The Plan

Once I have raised the funds and have returned to training I will also be working closely with Scottish Athletics to help establish better opportunities for disabled athletics within Edinburgh. With my coaching experience and my own racing chair I intend to help make disablity athletics a much more accesable activity for others.

Please help by donating and sharing my goal with others either online or by word of mouth.

story:
"Children like Kelly, who endure so much, and emerge, looking as if nothing had ever happened, are the reason I do what I do. And if her mother can "pay it forward" and make this game happen, I'll be on the sidelines cheering with her." 
      David Loeb, MD, PhD Pediatric Oncologist, Johns Hopkins Hospital    

My daughter Kelly was 10 years old when she became violently and potentially fatally ill. After more than 2 years of various hospital stays, countless tests and incorrect diagnoses here in California, by the grace of God, we got her to Johns Hopkins Hospital & University in Baltimore where she was ultimately properly diagnosed & treated. She had a very rare autoimmune condition called collagenous gastroentercolitis, which means that her body was literally eating itself alive. She was given a chemotherapy drug called Cyclophosphamide (high-dose Cytoxen), not knowing if it would work, as it had only been used a few times on children with compromised immune systems. It re-booted her immune system and she slowly but surely kept getting better and better. She is now back to the healthy & vibrant girl she once was. Nothing short of a miracle, really. Since her recovery, this treatment has now been opened up and offered to children who would have otherwise not been eligible due to a shortage of research funding and awareness for orphan diseases such as this. After watching my daughter being ushered to death's door, and then witnessing her literally coming back to life, I am faced with an overwhelming need to pay my blessings forward and to do everything in my power to make sure that this life-saving research continues. No child or family should ever have to ride this kind of a roller coaster.

"Under the Friday Night Lights" is in honor of my daughter and the doctors who saved her life, and is a fundraising football game/concert to benefit childhood research at the #1 hospital in the world...Johns Hopkins. With its critical mass of world-class expertise, culture and cross-disciplinary collaboration and proven results, Johns Hopkins is leading the way to treatment and cure of childhood diseases. The game will raise money for (and hopefully awareness of) the plethora of illnesses that can strike a child at any given time without notice. It will bring this very worthy cause to light and bring the grand necessity of this research front and center.

What We Need & What You Get

Kelly was finally well enough to cheer for her high school football team (which was her only dream during her lengthy illness), who, during her senior year, went completely undefeated, even all the way through playoffs. They were and still are an amazing group of young men. Our small town of Windsor, California has so many similarities to the fictional town of Dillon, Texas, the setting for the TV series "Friday Night Lights," all the way down to the personalities of the main characters vs. our real-life Windsor Jaguars. So what better way to celebrate life than by playing a charity football game??? We are officially challenging the cast of FNL to come up to Windsor and play against our undefeated Jags! The funding we would receive from you would go directly toward getting Kelly's story to the powers that be who developed the series, which would involve a business plan, promotional items (video, copyright permission, etc.), travel expenses, securing the field and a date, jerseys for the players, and going after major corporate sponsorship. Any funding above and beyond our needs would go directly to the Oncology and Immunology Research Departments at Johns Hopkins. Should the event fail to take place, any unused funds would go to those entities as well. I'd really like to have the event filmed so everyone could see it, not just Windsor or Sonoma County residents. That's also something I'd ask for in my pursuit, even if it's only something that you could watch online.

After the game, there will be a live band on the field for everyone, patron & participant alike, to enjoy and to celebrate all that we will have achieved! A little fun to go with the fun, if you will...!

The Impact

This project (and others like it) are potentially invaluable to the Oncology and Immunology Research communities. Our immune systems are responsible for every single cell and function in our bodies. None of us are exempt. Even something as simple as having seasonal allergies stems from the immune system. The reason I chose to do a benefit for Johns Hopkins is not quite as simple as you might think. While it's true that their doctors & research saved my daughter's life, it goes even further than that...they actually share their information with other health organizations so that the WORLD may benefit from it, not just their community or those who are lucky enough to get there. The same cannot be said for most research facilities, even places like St. Jude. In addition, Hopkins has been the top hospital AND research facility for the majority of the last 20 years, so that should speak for itself.

Many of you may not know this, but before Kelly was born, I was a local band manager and promoter and I produced several benefits each year for local charities in the Bay Area. It was always my dream to resume that work when Kelly was a bit older, but when she got sick, I had to put all of that on the back burner. So in a way, I'm kind of picking up where I left off, but on a much grander scale, and for far more personal reasons. If I had the resources, I would do this every single year.

Risks & Challenges

Obviously, there are endless challenges and potential obstacles in my way in producing an event of this magnitude. I'm not gonna lie, this will be a huge undertaking, for sure, and at times, it will get overwhelming. But in all honesty, that's really what keeps me motivated! My bands (all 5 of them) gave me the name "Super K" many years ago, because there was nothing I wouldn't do or try for any of them. Together, we all achieved more than any of us ever dreamed we could. And I'm proud to say that to this very day, my reputation is still intact and as good as it was all those years ago. I believe that we are all in this game of life together, and that none of us are better than any other, regardless of "what side of the tracks" we come from. When Kelly got sick, it was almost as if I stepped out of my life and my role as her mother and became her protector and staunch advocate instead. That was the only way I was going to get through it. In a way, I was "managing" her health care. The risks were huge, and I had to walk a very fine line to keep the peace between her caregivers and our family on a daily basis. Her life literally depended on it. I did what I had to do, but I did it with respect and dignity, because if the tables were turned, that's what I would hope for and expect from others. After all that I've been through and watching my daughter waste away before my very eyes, dare I say, I'm really not afraid of anything anymore. Throw something in front of me and I'll either climb over it or go around it...or maybe I'll just walk right through it, but I WILL get to the other side!


    Other Ways You Can Help

    For those who may be unable to contribute monetarily, helping me spread the word would be just as valuable. Or for local folks, volunteering a service or helping at the event would be great. As I've said, I can't do this by myself. Together, we can all make this happen. There are share tools on the Indiegogo site that can help you help me, and, in turn, help the cause.
story_txt:
"Children like Kelly, who endure so much, and emerge, looking as if nothing had ever happened, are the reason I do what I do. And if her mother can "pay it forward" and make this game happen, I'll be on the sidelines cheering with her."        David Loeb, MD, PhD Pediatric Oncologist, Johns Hopkins Hospital     My daughter Kelly was 10 years old when she became violently and potentially fatally ill. After more than 2 years of various hospital stays, countless tests and incorrect diagnoses here in California, by the grace of God, we got her to Johns Hopkins Hospital & University in Baltimore where she was ultimately properly diagnosed & treated. She had a very rare autoimmune condition called collagenous gastroentercolitis, which means that her body was literally eating itself alive. She was given a chemotherapy drug called Cyclophosphamide (high-dose Cytoxen), not knowing if it would work, as it had only been used a few times on children with compromised immune systems. It re-booted her immune system and she slowly but surely kept getting better and better. She is now back to the healthy & vibrant girl she once was. Nothing short of a miracle, really. Since her recovery, this treatment has now been opened up and offered to children who would have otherwise not been eligible due to a shortage of research funding and awareness for orphan diseases such as this. After watching my daughter being ushered to death's door, and then witnessing her literally coming back to life, I am faced with an overwhelming need to pay my blessings forward and to do everything in my power to make sure that this life-saving research continues. No child or family should ever have to ride this kind of a roller coaster."Under the Friday Night Lights" is in honor of my daughter and the doctors who saved her life, and is a fundraising football game/concert to benefit childhood research at the #1 hospital in the world...Johns Hopkins. With its critical mass of world-class expertise, culture and cross-disciplinary collaboration and proven results, Johns Hopkins is leading the way to treatment and cure of childhood diseases. The game will raise money for (and hopefully awareness of) the plethora of illnesses that can strike a child at any given time without notice. It will bring this very worthy cause to light and bring the grand necessity of this research front and center. 
  What We Need & What You GetKelly was finally well enough to cheer for her high school football team (which was her only dream during her lengthy illness), who, during her senior year, went completely undefeated, even all the way through playoffs. They were and still are an amazing group of young men. Our small town of Windsor, California has so many similarities to the fictional town of Dillon, Texas, the setting for the TV series "Friday Night Lights," all the way down to the personalities of the main characters vs. our real-life Windsor Jaguars. So what better way to celebrate life than by playing a charity football game??? We are officially challenging the cast of FNL to come up to Windsor and play against our undefeated Jags! The funding we would receive from you would go directly toward getting Kelly's story to the powers that be who developed the series, which would involve a business plan, promotional items (video, copyright permission, etc.), travel expenses, securing the field and a date, jerseys for the players, and going after major corporate sponsorship. Any funding above and beyond our needs would go directly to the Oncology and Immunology Research Departments at Johns Hopkins. Should the event fail to take place, any unused funds would go to those entities as well. I'd really like to have the event filmed so everyone could see it, not just Windsor or Sonoma County residents. That's also something I'd ask for in my pursuit, even if it's only something that you could watch online. After the game, there will be a live band on the field for everyone, patron & participant alike, to enjoy and to celebrate all that we will have achieved! A little fun to go with the fun, if you will...!
  The ImpactThis project (and others like it) are potentially invaluable to the Oncology and Immunology Research communities. Our immune systems are responsible for every single cell and function in our bodies. None of us are exempt. Even something as simple as having seasonal allergies stems from the immune system. The reason I chose to do a benefit for Johns Hopkins is not quite as simple as you might think. While it's true that their doctors & research saved my daughter's life, it goes even further than that...they actually share their information with other health organizations so that the WORLD may benefit from it, not just their community or those who are lucky enough to get there. The same cannot be said for most research facilities, even places like St. Jude. In addition, Hopkins has been the top hospital AND research facility for the majority of the last 20 years, so that should speak for itself.Many of you may not know this, but before Kelly was born, I was a local band manager and promoter and I produced several benefits each year for local charities in the Bay Area. It was always my dream to resume that work when Kelly was a bit older, but when she got sick, I had to put all of that on the back burner. So in a way, I'm kind of picking up where I left off, but on a much grander scale, and for far more personal reasons. If I had the resources, I would do this every single year.
  Risks & Challenges
Obviously, there are endless challenges and potential obstacles in my way in producing an event of this magnitude. I'm not gonna lie, this will be a huge undertaking, for sure, and at times, it will get overwhelming. But in all honesty, that's really what keeps me motivated! My bands (all 5 of them) gave me the name "Super K" many years ago, because there was nothing I wouldn't do or try for any of them. Together, we all achieved more than any of us ever dreamed we could. And I'm proud to say that to this very day, my reputation is still intact and as good as it was all those years ago. I believe that we are all in this game of life together, and that none of us are better than any other, regardless of "what side of the tracks" we come from. When Kelly got sick, it was almost as if I stepped out of my life and my role as her mother and became her protector and staunch advocate instead. That was the only way I was going to get through it. In a way, I was "managing" her health care. The risks were huge, and I had to walk a very fine line to keep the peace between her caregivers and our family on a daily basis. Her life literally depended on it. I did what I had to do, but I did it with respect and dignity, because if the tables were turned, that's what I would hope for and expect from others. After all that I've been through and watching my daughter waste away before my very eyes, dare I say, I'm really not afraid of anything anymore. Throw something in front of me and I'll either climb over it or go around it...or maybe I'll just walk right through it, but I WILL get to the other side!

story:
Brandon is in critical condition.

  • After many years suffering in silence from anxiety and depression, our beloved son, brother and uncle is in critical condition at an out of town hospital. He was rushed by ambulance on September 23, 2014 to our local hospital. We were unaware of his condition until he called 911 and could not walk. 

He was placed in intensive care due to liver failure and kidney failure along with many other medical problems. The need for dialysis was urgent and our small town hospital does not have the means to treat him properly. He was transferred to a hospital in a bigger city so he can get the life saving treatment he needs. 

We are asking for help with expenses we will incur as a result of the long commute to be near him, he will need aftercare and possibly a liver transplant.

With your much needed help, we, his family, will be able to be with him in his time of need. No amount is too small and we thank you in advance.

Please check out Brandon's webpage and youtube video on the tab to get a picture of the kind soul he is.

story:
No Time Wheysted’s number priority is to provide assistance for individuals and help them achieve their bodybuilding and fitness goals.

In doing so, we will provide a variety of resources from credible sources ranging from articles and videos that will educate the wider community on fitness facts, all for FREE. We understand that everyone is capable of finding their own information through the internet, however it can often take hours on end sifting and sorting through data especially when there are so many contradictions in the fitness world. We understand how valuable the commodity of time is and recognise that no one wants to spend countless hours finding information, particularly if it’s incorrect, so why not leave that job for us, and instead spend your time efficiently implementing accurate fitness tips from one main resource, No Time Wheysted.

Our ambitions as company isn’t simply just to provide correct information, as we also pride ourselves on staying ahead of the curb, so that we can impart new bodybuilding & fitness knowledge to our community, as well as striving to help motivate and inspire a new generation of healthy and fit individuals.

In addition, our goals to encourage people to get in shape and reach their fitness goals not only will bring satisfaction to everyone that succeeds, but it also illustrates that no goal is impossible. Bodybuilding and fitness is very much of a mental task then it is a physical one, and we believe that the mindset created and developed in the gym is able to be transferred to any aspect of life. As a result, NTW aims to inspire people to breaking new goals and setting new heights with their body, to set an example for other aspects of their life. For what it’s worth, we also aim to remove the void of hesitation, self-doubt and being stagnant and instead replace it by a sense of determination, to willingly chase after any dream or ambition, no matter how hard they may be. 

Finally, there is one more thing we also wish to achieve and that is to grow this bodybuilding and the fitness industry as a whole, through helping athletes all over the word gain the recognition they deserve. We already have some very big athletes that have been interviewed, but wish to hold them off until we attain a new website.

At the moment we have very limited resources to make this movement a reality and need YOUR help to make this possible. Until then, we will do our best and work with what we have to provide you guys the information you need to achieve your own ambitions. 


  


In order for No Time Wheysted to become the ultimate resource for bodybuilding and fitness, we require $7,500 to cover the necessary costs. This will include the expenses for the designers and programmers used to develop our new platform.

Mind you that this money will not go to creating an average website. We aim to create a platform that will be visually pleasing while also having a remarkable interface, so that it will be an accessible and friendly website for our community. Some of the top tier websites that we’ll try to model our new platform around include sbnation.com and bleacherreport.com, both of which are at the top of their industry.

You can visit our current website at: www.notimewheysted.com 

We are getting quite an impression from our current site, but are still far from where we wish to be. As a result, we require a new site so that we are not limited with our options and are able to implement the necessary steps to creating the number one resource for bodybuilding and fitness.

Your donation to this campaign will contribute to:

-  Designing our new website with a high end freelancer(s)

-  Paying the programmer(s) (Turn the PSD into a CMS)

-  A motivational video that will illustrate NTW’s purpose and vision 

The more donations raised, the faster we can grow and the more we can help you in achieving your ambitions in and outside the gym. 



Our Team NoTimeWheysted T-shirts from our motivational life. This will be an exclusive limited edition T-Shirt that will only be provided for those willing to lend a helping hand. We will begin to finalise our design as soon as this campaign builds traction.

We will have a range of quotes to choose from:

·  Motivated by Time. Driven by Results

·  It’s You Vs The Iron.

More to come!

Provide us with a name and a size.
Sizes will range from Small – XL. It will also be made from 100% Cotton.

Our supplement stack has not been finalised yet, but we will include three to four supplements ranging from dextrose, whey and/or casein, pre-workout, mass gainers and more.

Note: All donations for ANY perk will automatically win you 1 raffle ticket that will provide you the opportunity to win an amazing supplement pack and a Team NTW T-shirt with a combined valued at $250. The raffle will be held immediately after the campaign, and the winner will be notified that very day. Be sure to leave your full name and contact details when you donate. 

To increase your chances, raffle tickets will be given to those that share this campaign via Facebook at the top of the page OR with a post and tag on instagram: ‘@Notimewheysted.com & #teamntw’ 


If you are unable to financially contribute to the campaign, you still can play a vital role by sharing this link on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and all other social media platforms.

story:
Short Summary

Hello there! Welcome to our project! We are three high school students who are starting up an organization to give back to our amazing Toronto community. Our goal is to provide hospital and retirement home waiting rooms with beautiful photo books packed with our original photographs taken from places all around the world. This is all in an effort to accelerate recovery in patients, as well as brighten the mood of everyone who visits. 

What We Need

Well I'm glad you asked, Internet friend! We are asking for $1000 to fund our project.
We have created a stunning 20 page, full page, full colour, photo book complete with our own photos from our various adventures. We are all passionate photographers and want to use our work for good, so we want to print 20 of these books and hand deliver them to Toronto medical buildings and retirement homes!
Visit our website www.awheart.com to view the photos that will be included in the book, and please email us at contact.artwithheart@gmail.com if you would like to suggest a waiting room in need of some uplifting art! 

The money raised here will also be used to pay for our website, that when this campaign is over, will be open for people to sponsor a photo book and choose where they want it to be donated. A small portion of the funds raised in this campaign will be used to print and deliver the prints and photo books to our Silver, Gold and Platinum Sponsors! 

If we don't reach our ambitious $1000 goal in 60 days, we will simply lower the number of photo books that will be donated to fit the amount raised, and those books will still find a happy home in a waiting room near you. 

If we raise more than $1000 we will print and donate as many photo books as we can possibly afford! Check back on our website www.awheart.com and our Twitter @ArtWithHeart14 to see our progress!

Please note! We are not yet a not for profit organisation as we are raising the funds to do so! This means we are not yet legally allowed to issue tax receipts!

Perks

We have 4 different perks available; Bronze, Silver, Gold, and Platinum, and all donors will be listed as a sponsor at the back of our photo books.
You can find the descriptions for the perks on the right. For those that require image selection (Silver, Gold, and Platinum), please write down the item code of the photo you would like (photos and item codes can be found at www.awheart.com/ourgalleries/), and email us at contact.artwithheart@gmail.com with the information!

    The Impact

    There have been scientific studies that show that art can help patients recover faster and manage pain better. The art, however, has to be the right art – vivid paintings of landscapes, friendly faces and familiar objects can lower blood pressure and heart rate, In one study, two university professors at Houston’s St. Luke’s Episcopal Hospital used two types of art. In the first group were images that have been proved to calm patients, including green landscapes, water scenes, cultural artifacts and emotionally expressive pictures of people. The second group contained abstract pieces. When asked which they preferred, most patients chose images from the first group (http://psychcentral.com/blog/archives/2009/09/01/can-art-improve-your-health/). The majority of our photographs (except for the empowering urban shots of course) fall into the group of landscapes and other forms of nature photography.
    A contribution to our project means that we can help those who need it the most during their time in a hospital or retirement home. You will have become part of our elite task force with the mission to keep our business going. Without your help, we would not be able to reach out to our community and improve the lives of the people there. 

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Can't contribute? No worries! Help us spread the word of our campaign to your family, friends, neighbours, and even to that nice cashier from the corner store. The campaign ends on December 26th, so you can even put "a donation to the Art With Heart Indiegogo campaign" on your holiday wish list! Also be sure to use Indiegogo's share tools to tell others, because hey, the more the merrier!

Also be sure to use Indiegogo's share tools to tell others, because hey, the more the merrier!

story:
My story

Hi. My name is Leigh Brandt. I'm 21, and I'm chronically ill.
I have a neurological disorder called hemicrania continua, which means I basically have a constant migraine with pain that averages 7.5/10, with frequent spikes of seriously intense pain that last anywhere from a couple seconds to a several days. 
In January 2014, I had a spike cluster that hit 10/10 and lasted five days. I ended up being admitted to the ER three times in two days, and after the third admission, the doctors decided to keep me in the hospital and to run diagnostic tests to make sure I wasn't having a stroke or that I had a brain tumour like my mother (she has a pituitary adenoma and surgical Addison's disease.) The tests all came back clean, and I was sent to a headache specialist in a large city 4 hours from where I live.
The next step in my treatment is a procedure that will cost about $3,700.
Because of the pain, I am unable to work, and my medical bills are crippling my mother financially. Last year, our medical bills (not including insurance premiums) totaled around $30,000. Mum has maxed out her credit cards and gone through her savings trying to keep us afloat, and we're deep in debt. I'm in the process of applying for disability, but right now, we really need help.
I really need help.

What I need

I'm trying to raise as much money as I can to pay for my medical bills. Any and all money raised by this campaign will go straight to paying the hospital bills and help pay for my treatments.

Any amount you can spare will be greatly, greatly appreciated.

And what I'll do for you

<$10 - Eternal gratitude and a long distance hug.

$10 - I will edit something for you. A paper for school, a chapter of your novel, a resume,  a poem, whatever you're working on that could use a second pair of eyes and a fresh perspective.

$15 - A video recording of your choice of songs I already know how to play; 

"Each Coming Night," "Love and Some Verses," "Naked As We Came" "Resurrection Fern," or "Sodom, South Georgia," by Iron And Wine.  

"Come Back Home," or "Wrecking Ball" by Chris Pureka

"Lua," or "First Day of My Life" by Bright Eyes, or

"Small Hands" by Keaton Henson.

$25 -  A video recording of an acoustic cover of your choice of songs.

>$30 - Pick a perk of your own!

The Impact

Your help will help relieve the burden of my medical bills and debt, and make it possible for me to continue treatment for my disorder.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute (I know how tight money can be), I'd really appreciate it if you'd pass the word along. 


Thank you,

Leigh
story_txt: My storyHi. My name is Leigh Brandt. I'm 21, and I'm chronically ill.I have a neurological disorder called hemicrania continua, which means I basically have a constant migraine with pain that averages 7.5/10, with frequent spikes of seriously intense pain that last anywhere from a couple seconds to a several days. In January 2014, I had a spike cluster that hit 10/10 and lasted five days. I ended up being admitted to the ER three times in two days, and after the third admission, the doctors decided to keep me in the hospital and to run diagnostic tests to make sure I wasn't having a stroke or that I had a brain tumour like my mother (she has a pituitary adenoma and surgical Addison's disease.) The tests all came back clean, and I was sent to a headache specialist in a large city 4 hours from where I live.The next step in my treatment is a procedure that will cost about $3,700.Because of the pain, I am unable to work, and my medical bills are crippling my mother financially. Last year, our medical bills (not including insurance premiums) totaled around $30,000. Mum has maxed out her credit cards and gone through her savings trying to keep us afloat, and we're deep in debt. I'm in the process of applying for disability, but right now, we really need help.I really need help.What I needI'm trying to raise as much money as I can to pay for my medical bills. Any and all money raised by this campaign will go straight to paying the hospital bills and help pay for my treatments.Any amount you can spare will be greatly, greatly appreciated.And what I'll do for you<$10 - Eternal gratitude and a long distance hug.$10 - I will edit something for you. A paper for school, a chapter of your novel, a resume,  a poem, whatever you're working on that could use a second pair of eyes and a fresh perspective.$15 - A video recording of your choice of songs I already know how to play; "Each Coming Night," "Love and Some Verses," "Naked As We Came" "Resurrection Fern," or "Sodom, South Georgia," by Iron And Wine.  "Come Back Home," or "Wrecking Ball" by Chris Pureka"Lua," or "First Day of My Life" by Bright Eyes, or"Small Hands" by Keaton Henson.$25 -  A video recording of an acoustic cover of your choice of songs.>$30 - Pick a perk of your own!The ImpactYour help will help relieve the burden of my medical bills and debt, and make it possible for me to continue treatment for my disorder.Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can't contribute (I know how tight money can be), I'd really appreciate it if you'd pass the word along. Thank you,Leigh

story:
Short Summary

FOUNDERS

Robert Morin is a board certified plastic surgeon with offices in NYC and New Jersey. He performs a wide range of cosmetic and reconstructive procedures.

Dr. Morin has a special interest in rhinoplasty and complex facial, nose and ear reconstruction. His accredited fellowship in craniofacial surgery, plastic surgery, pediatric plastic surgery and facial cosmetic surgery has given him the ability to perform complex surgical procedures on the faces of both children with cleft lips and palates, cleft nasal deformities and congenital deformities.

Dr. Morin donates one week of his time each year, and all of his skills, to children in developing countries throughout the world. In the United States, he works closely with neurosurgeons, surgical oncologists, dermatologists, and neonatologists in order to restore proper form and function to patients with traumatic injuries, congenital abnormalities and cancer.

Sue Kim received a B.S. in 2005 from Pennsylvania State University. She worked for numerous pharmaceutical and medical device companies before joining Scarguard Labs, where she currently is the Executive Vice President of Business Development.

Sue has experience raising funds for small businesses and start-ups and used those cultivated relationships to help non-profit organizations like Developing Faces, raise capital.

Sue has previously been involved with numerous volunteer organizations and charities with focus on babies and children before starting Developing Faces with Dr. Morin. Sue also represents Dr. Morin in all of his Public Relations & Marketing aspects.

Sue is currently working with the United Nations and the General Consul, to help build and modernize hospitals and medicine using her relationships with biotech and pharmaceutical companies and hospitals in the United States.

Campaign

Our mission is to to provide HIGH QUALITY surgical care to babies and children with facial abnormalities living in developing countries around the world. This year we are raising funds for our mission to Colombia where we will perform 25 surgeries to babies and children with cleft lips, missing ears, etc. Our surgical missions differ from other facial abnormality missions because our follow-up of care. Our medical board will do pre and post operative missions for the children, instead of relying on the surgeons in those developing countries.

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Funding needed: After breaking down every single need for the mission from the surgical instruments, OR needs, airfare, etc, we have established that the fund needs for this mission will be $364,000.00. All of this money will go directly to the 25 surgeries we will be performing with our medical board and everything leading up to it. 
  • If we do not reach our entire goal for the surgical mission, the funds will go directly to the next surgical mission in 2015, in Colombia as well.
  • Please donate for some of our great perks made with love

story:
World Foam League

The World Foam League is a Precision Point Combat based Entertainment Extravaganza. Where fighters create characters, choose a weapon (Made by Calimacil) and step into the ring. Six Rounds lasting One Minute will determine who is truly the Superior Fighter. Presented and Filmed in a WWE style. There are announcers ring side for each match. There are even camera's backstage catching the Behind the Scenes Drama between Fighters & Managers, 

  • Hello, I'm Samantha hull. wife ,mother and the owner of the WFL .
  • The WFL was founded by my husband and Fighter Jeremiah aka Thunder and was started just to be a way for him to let loose and have some fun with new people . But we soon seen that there was lots of people asking to see more. We were getting asked to come put on shows at Cons all over Florida and other places. Thats when we brought in CEO Frank White to help get this going and he told us about indiegogo to help with getting the ring made in time for the 1st WFL show at Ultracon of South Florida in Dec.
  • With this Ring we will be able to shoot the promo videos we need and hold the ranking fights before the 1st show in dec. Basically without this ring the wfl is dead in the water and the the dream of what we made here will be a out of reach fantasy.

What is needed for the WFL and What is the WFL offering to you.

  • First thing that is needed is the metal piping that will be welded to make the inner locking panels and braces to the ring frame, around $500. Next we will need the 3 part ring floor made using wood, foam and carpet around $600. Then we will need the foam used for around the ring and on the ground around $600 . Which leaves around $300 for welding supplies . we are having a friend that donated his welder and time work on this, we are just needing the supplies to make the dream a reality .  

What happens to the money if the goal is not made?

  • Well if the goal is not made we will use what we made towards getting the ring made , Failure is not a option,  

Perks

  • Since this is just for the WFL ring being made we are offering to every one that gives to have Credit with name of choice on a page on the WFL website with video of the making of the ring.We will also thank every one on the video,
  • If you give $100 or more we will put your name of choice on a plaque to be mounted on the WFL ring.

The Impact 

A new concept in sports (Precision point combat) that combines the best of the WWE with its over the top theatrics and outrageous characters ,the realism of the UFC and the weapons of LARP . Featuring male and female fighters from all walks of life, battling in a combat circle using only the best in foam rubber weapons.

All fighters have a unique character , as well as a distinctive costume. Fighters wear whatever kind of makeup or costume they desire, and fight with the foam rubber weapon of their choosing.

WFL fights are not staged or choreographed in any way. Fighters are real athletes who use real skills to determine the outcome of the fights and once again reclaim their glory .

  • The WFL is the best of all the things i love , with the acting and drama to the real life fights that make warriors face off, use quick thinking and skills not just bruit strength to win. Not that bruit strength doesnt help but unlike most contact entertainment sports, even the little guy can be a giant in the ring.

Here is a practice fight at Ultracon with no blood packs and ring,


     Challenges

    We still have a long road ahead of us, from getting the best athletes and staff to getting every thing else needed to make the WFL world wide with chapters all over and  100s of fighters eager to put on a good show just for you,.

    • But we have hired and are hiring on the best staff to organize and motivate this dream and make it reality .

      latest info on the One and Only Ultra-Con Of South Florida

    No Cash? You Can still Help

    We understand Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

    • You can all help by posting this and showing all your friends ,
    • and dont forget about Indiegogo share tools!

    Dont forget to come by and check us out on FaceBook
